transcript:
Patient: That sounds good to me. I'm open to reviewing the techniques we've covered so far and troubleshooting any challenges I've had.

Therapist: Great. Let's start with the Positive Data Log. Can you share an entry where you successfully challenged the belief that you must always put others' needs before your own?

Patient: Sure. Last week, my child asked me to help them with a school project, but I had already planned to attend a virtual support group for non-binary individuals. In the past, I would have canceled my plans to help my child. But this time, I explained to them that I had a prior commitment and offered to help them later in the evening. It was difficult, but I managed to prioritize my own needs while still being supportive.

Therapist: That's a fantastic example of finding a balance between your own needs and the needs of others. How did it feel to set that boundary and prioritize your support group?

Patient: It felt empowering, but also a bit scary. I was worried that my child would be upset with me or think I didn't care about their project. But they actually understood and appreciated that I had my own commitments.

Therapist: That's a great insight. It shows that setting boundaries doesn't mean you're being selfish or uncaring. In fact, it can lead to healthier relationships built on mutual understanding and respect. Let's add this example to your Positive Data Log as evidence against the belief that you must always put others' needs first.

Patient: That makes sense. I guess I need to keep reminding myself that setting boundaries is okay and doesn't make me a bad person.

Therapist: Exactly. And that's where your coping card can come in handy. Speaking of which, how have you been using your coping card this week?

Patient: I've been trying to read through it every morning to start my day with a more balanced perspective. And like I mentioned earlier, I used it when I was feeling particularly overwhelmed and guilty. It helped me challenge those negative thoughts in the moment.

Therapist: That's great to hear. Using the coping card proactively, like reading it every morning, is a wonderful way to reinforce those new, adaptive thoughts. And using it in moments of distress can help you self-soothe and challenge negative thoughts as they arise.

Patient: It's definitely been helpful, but sometimes I still struggle with believing the affirmations on the card. It feels like I'm just telling myself lies.

Therapist: That's a common experience when challenging long-held beliefs. It takes time and practice to internalize new, more balanced thoughts. One technique we can use is to look for evidence that supports the affirmations on your coping card. For example, let's take the affirmation "I am worthy of love and acceptance, even when I prioritize my own needs." Can you think of a time when you prioritized your own needs and still felt loved and accepted?

Patient: Well, there was the time I went to my support group instead of immediately helping my child with their project. They didn't get upset with me, and we still had a nice evening together after I got back.

Therapist: That's a perfect example. It directly challenges the belief that you're only worthy of love and acceptance when you prioritize others' needs. The more you can identify and reflect on experiences like this, the more you'll start to believe the affirmations on your coping card.

Patient: I see what you mean. It's about finding real-life evidence to support these new beliefs.

Therapist: Exactly. And that's something we can continue to work on together. Another technique that can be helpful is role reversal. Let's pretend that I'm the one struggling with the belief that I must always put others' needs first. What advice would you give me?

Patient: Hmm, I guess I would tell you that it's okay to have your own needs and desires. That setting boundaries and prioritizing self-care doesn't make you selfish or unloving. And that taking care of yourself can actually help you be more present and supportive in your relationships.

Therapist: That's excellent advice, Jamie. And it applies to you as well. By role-playing, you're able to see the situation from a different perspective and offer compassion and understanding to yourself.

Patient: It's definitely easier to give that advice than to take it myself. But I see your point.

Therapist: It's a process, and you're making great progress. As we continue to work together, you'll find it easier to internalize these new beliefs and show yourself the same compassion you offer others.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I appreciate your support and guidance.

Therapist: You're welcome, Jamie. I'm here to support you every step of the way. Remember, challenging long-held beliefs takes time and practice, but you're doing the work, and that's what matters most.
